channel.title: Opening .class files
channel.description: What program do I need to open up .class files? Thanks for the help =)

item.title: Opening .class files
item.dc:creator: @usman555 usman555
item.description:
@usman555 wrote:

Opium10:

I think you should gtfo you smart ass.

You said no shit about .java files being compiled. Read your own shit before you comment on others.

Read full topic

item.title: Opening .class files
item.dc:creator: @Opium10 Opium10
item.description:
@Opium10 wrote:

[quote=“iCreatedHorror, post:6, topic:349195”][quote author=Opium10 link=topic=445565.msg3271031#msg3271031 date=1279204826]

.class files are encrypted. These .class files are created everytime you compile your server (the .java gets encrypted).
You edit the .java, compile, and the .class is created. I believe this is how the server reads it.

Someone correct me if I’m wrong, although I believe that is the general idea.
@Opium, you edit .java with notepad too if you want, not just CFG.

If you’re reading a tut and they say client class, that means the client.java
client class = client.java
client.class = client.class

I’m pretty sure that’s what i said above.
[/quote]
You said NOTHING about the .java being edited, then compiling to create the .class files, so shut it.
All you said was that you edit CFG with notepad. There are programs to decrypt .class, but as far as I know, there is no point.
And also, in most tuts, they refer to .java files as “NAME class” not “NAME.java”
So by what you put he could get confused…[/quote]
I think you should gtfo you smart ass.

Read full topic

item.title: Opening .class files
item.dc:creator: @iCreatedHorror Ryan
item.description:
@iCreatedHorror wrote:

[quote=“Opium10, post:5, topic:349195”][quote author=iCreatedHorror link=topic=445565.msg3271029#msg3271029 date=1279204632]
.class files are encrypted. These .class files are created everytime you compile your server (the .java gets encrypted).
You edit the .java, compile, and the .class is created. I believe this is how the server reads it.

Someone correct me if I’m wrong, although I believe that is the general idea.
@Opium, you edit .java with notepad too if you want, not just CFG.

If you’re reading a tut and they say client class, that means the client.java
client class = client.java
client.class = client.class
[/quote]
I’m pretty sure that’s what i said above.[/quote]
You said NOTHING about the .java being edited, then compiling to create the .class files, so shut it.
All you said was that you edit CFG with notepad. There are programs to decrypt .class, but as far as I know, there is no point.
And also, in most tuts, they refer to .java files as “NAME class” not “NAME.java”
So by what you put he could get confused…

Read full topic

You edit the .java, compile, and the .class is created. I believe this is how the server reads it.

Someone correct me if I’m wrong, although I believe that is the general idea.
@Opium, you edit .java with notepad too if you want, not just CFG.

item.title: Opening .class files
item.dc:creator: @iCreatedHorror Ryan
item.description:
@iCreatedHorror wrote:

.class files are encrypted. These .class files are created everytime you compile your server (the .java gets encrypted).
You edit the .java, compile, and the .class is created. I believe this is how the server reads it.

Someone correct me if I’m wrong, although I believe that is the general idea.
@Opium, you edit .java with notepad too if you want, not just CFG.

If you’re reading a tut and they say client class, that means the client.java
client class = client.java
client.class = client.class

item.title: Opening .class files
item.dc:creator: @Opium10 Opium10
item.description:
@Opium10 wrote:

[quote=“99range k0, post:1, topic:349195”]What program do I need to open up .class files?
Thanks for the help =)[/quote]
A class file is the same as a note pad but it goes encrypted. [Notepad] [To see encrypted shit]
Cfg files you edit with notepad.
